dr.kholi: Make sure you give her alllll the things to chew. Like to set a chewing habit for her so her teeth will stay awesome longer than most small dogs. Make a system of consistently giving her things that are hers (and also being in charge of taking them away). So she can learn agency, but also learn what is hers vs yours and that you are pack leader. And you know I could go on and on. 😂 ESPECIALLY when it comes to treats and food.

stencilista: Congrats! I’ve been working in the veterinary field for 12 years and the best piece of advice I can share is to get pet insurance! At our veterinary hospital we recommend Healthy Paws or Trupanion. I have insurance for my pets, despite having a major discount for working at a vet. It’s totally worth it, because those babies will throw you for a loop!
roguepoet_: Dog daycare attendant here. Take her everywhere, get her used to dogs, cats, people, crowds, everything in between, and as many noises and sights as you can expose her to and as early as possible. Make sure she associates as much of it with positivity as possible. (Carrots are a great non fattening treat to use here FYI) Ignore bad behaviour and praise the hell out of ALL wanted behaviour consistently. You’ll probably see this everywhere but I can’t stress how important proper socialization and the ability to self regulate becomes as they grow. Being assertive is not the same as being “mean” as well. You and your dog can have a wonderful loving relationship and can train without any force while still being assertive and respecting the roles you two play in your relationship. Crate training is a must as well. A well trained and stimulated dog with a job to do, no matter how small, is a happy dog. Check out stimulus challenges on dog training accounts- some of them are really fun and your pup will have a blast with them.
carolinekj0nes: congrats!!! that’s one lucky pup!! I don’t have much advice since I haven’t had a pup since 2005, but know that it’s okay to make mistakes. at the end of the day, the two of you will always be perfect in baguette’s eyes and you will always be that baby dog’s world❤️❤️
k.elseyk: I agree with the comments about crate training— great idea. Also, Kong toys that you hide a treat inside are great for puppy energy and chewing tendencies. I would suggest getting little mini treats for positive reinforcement/reward-based training (sit, stay, come, etc). Teach her to stay out of the area while you’re eating if you want to avoid future begging. Socialize, socialize, socialize!! I would suggest watching some basic training videos on YouTube before issues even arise because they’re overall a great glimpse into dog psychology. Being the best owner you can possibly be is definitely a learning process but it’ll set your lil family up for success :) Good luck!!
notsosocialsharma: Don’t let her puppy face get to you. As difficult as it’ll be, be strict now so you don’t have to later. If she’s teething, keep your favorite shoes and socks beyond her reach. Animals don’t care about organic food, feel free to feed them normal dog food or scrapes off your plate but feed her in her bowl at all times or she’ll get used to jumping on you (or your guests) when eating. So excited for all the licks and love that’s on your way. Happy parenting!
sharlenekemler: Milo can’t wait to meet his new friend
skobos: Positive reinforcement training for everything! Always have treats in your pocket!
ashangrila: Awwww soooo cute! The way they are looking up at Eb in the last picture 😭
jerrickahill: Baby wipes are a really good substitute for a bath, especially for things like other dog’s drool caked on the fur, or a muddy undercarriage from a rainy day walk.
fara.oana: OMG 😲😲😲hope 🥖X starts feeling at home with you too soon ❣️
itscyndel: Get X accustomed to brushing ASAP! That soft fur will gets matted faster than you can imagine! I waited too long with my puppy because he would chew the brush 😂 so I thought he needed time to mature, but then training him to be brushed was dramatic! Best of luck with her!
emma_bosley: Get pet insurance now! Both working in the vet industry and having two dogs that have had major surgeries and chronic issues, IT IS WORTH IT. In case you don’t know, pet insurances will either not cover pets or charge exorbitant fees once they even have been diagnosed with something as innocuous as an ear infection. Do it now before that adorable puppy eats something, gets a UTI, or needs surgery. Love to you and your new Baguette! 🥖

reenbean: Soooooooo adorable! So happy for your beautiful family ♥️
rileyandlunaadventure: All the chew toys! Setting boundaries and teaching them young is so important. You guys are going to be amazing doggie parents and that is one loved baby.
thebrownbunch5: Yay!! I have a little cockapoo too. They are so smart, good natured, gentle and eager to please! I would suggest that whatever door you'll be using to let her outside to use the bathroom, put a bell hanging from a string on the door and before you take her out, use her paw to hit the bell and then take her out to "potty" and eventually she will associate the sound of the bell with using the washroom and begin to ring it herself to let you know when she has to tinkle lol! 😅 Ours picked it up quickly and it was really helpful to us in her house training. X is adorable!! Best wishes together! 💖😍
chubbyavrillavigne: OMG THE FAMILY❤️❤️❤️❤️ this is toooo sweet !!!! 😍😍😍❤️
de.vorah: OMG! Mazel Tov!!! 😍  I have tons of puppy advice if you ever need any help! I am a dog trainer and would be happy to give you any info I have! :) DM me if you ever want any specifics! :)💗 Biggest piece of advice — create positive environments and teach puppy to enjoy learning before teaching specific skills or tricks. They need to feel inspired to learn/safe first, that way it feels fun and not like a chore (this is a little different when you train working breeds) . :) Most of it is common sense/psychological once you get into it! 💗  I always remind myself and others not to scold or punish young dogs unless you are absolutely positive the dog knows what you are asking for (and don’t scold harshly ever, as I am sure you already know! Try to redirect vs. scold with young dogs... think “I see you tried that, let’s try this instead”) — so, if you just taught your puppy to sit, don’t say “no” to the puppy until it’s been sitting for months and really understands the behavior. :) 💓💗💓 The two of you will be amazing puppy parents! Congratulations! L’chaim! 💗❤️💗:)

rati_femina: Omg. So cute.💗 Just raise the puppy u feel is best. With love.
jace_menzell: It’s dry, but read The Culture Clash by Jean Donaldson. She’s at the forefront of the fear-free/force-free positive reinforcement training tip. All based on behavioral science and fostering confident happy dogs! Guide for everything from potty training to socialization, etc. Socialization window closes at 12-14 weeks, so it’s especially important to take puppy to experience as many new people, things, sounds, other puppies, etc with LOTS of constant reinforcement so that they learn the world is a fun (and not scary) place. Hit me up if you’re looking for more specific resources!
erika.anne: CONGRATULATIONS!!!!!! My fave training books are by the monks of new skete - the art of training a puppy and how to be your dogs best friend. Best advice for forming a bond is tie a leash to your waist and have them follow you everywhere even at home - they learn to look to you for what to do 😭 and that most behavioral issues can be solved by letting them sleep in your bedroom so they feel the pack bond. The unconditional love of a dog is one of the best things in life, so thrilled for you 💜💜💜

girlscoutboy: Someone has definitely probably mentioned this but- Training from the get go is so important!! The pup has to know they are at the lowest level in the pack and you are the alpha. Otherwise you might have a million and one issues with peeing in the house and biting and barking!
magitaitaita: Baguette is adorable and has a great name! Things that helped me with my small dog (I had a husky growing up but now I have an Italian greyhound): front-clip harness—mine is SENSE-ation—helps with teaching how to walk without going all over the place, and a dremmel to file instead of clipping nails. Also, get started brushing teeth because smaller dogs have more dental issues and doggy dentists get expensive. Finally, I highly recommend crate training, our dog has a little separation anxiety and it helps having a set routine for us leaving the house. Congratulations from this doggy helicopter mom!

exxstazee: Puppies are kind of dicks tbh puppy proof by hiding everything you love lol but SO ADORABLE and SO WORTH IT 😍 Cesar Milan “CHHHH” is the most useful tool I’ve used and puppy classes are mandatory! Also Good socialization & exposure 😩 such a cutie!!!!! ❤❤❤
mixolidia: @zakgeorge has a free 30 day training course online sponsored by @pupford. It’s really good at starting puppy off right. Also learn to cut their nails and get them used to being bathed as soon as possible. As a puppy the nails are really soft so a small nail clipper will help get Baguette used to the pressure on the nails. There’s a nail maintenance group on Facebook that teaches positive reinforcement to trim the nails. And how to best trim the nails. Cutting off little slivers instead of a big chunk is best and be careful with the quick. Trust me you want your dog to learn to trust the clippers now as you may already know. Also, poo breeds can be deceptive for hair breeding. Talk to your groomer. You’ll probably need to brush their hair daily.
mraen7: Be patient & remember that they are literally like human babies/toddlers until they are at least a year old. Get bells for the door to signal bathroom time outside & pay for quality food, saves you $$$ in the long run with the vet and problems that arise from poor nutrition

bruteusmaximus: Aside from good luck, LOTS of patience and don't let any bad habits go unchecked for too long. Puppies love to test boundaries. Positive reinforcement works best, and enjoy your new addition! I love talking about dogs so please let me help if you have any more questions lolol

megssnopek: So cute!!! Congratulations! A couple puppy tips: set a timer for every 2 hours, and make sure to let the pup out - that’s how often they need to pee, so if they don’t do it make a note of it and let them out every 15 minutes or so until they do! (House training is much easier when it’s preventative, rather than trying to react to them peeing in the house). Also, clicker training is so helpful!!!! Grab a clicker and use it for everything, tricks and for them peeing/pooping outside. Give them tiny little treats as reinforcement and it is SO helpful
nocturnalreignbow: Baguette look like a straight up stuffed animal!!! Y’all so cute 😍
branolive: Do not use a retractable leash. It gives the puppy too much power, and it makes you and your dog less safe. It also sets up other dogs that may have anxiety to be triggered.
blkmoonlight: Touch their feet and ears often. I would also just open their mouth a few times like you’re checking their teeth just for the heck of it. This helps with smooth grooming and vet visits. Puppy training for commands. Definitely crate train. Folks like to train puppies to use the paper pads but I’m really not into condoning any potty action in the house. So with crate training, take bby outside frequently throughout the day. Take them with you wherever you can to socialize them with adults, kids, other dogs, babies, folks in wheelchairs or who use other mobility devices, loud sounds, etc. I would avoid giving them any human food unless you’ve made it specifically for them. This helps cut the begging for food.

m_a_mcdonald: Definitely get hold of Linda Michael’s Do No Harm handbook, and Dr Sophia Yin’s puppy book, and her low stress handling techniques etc. Dr Patricia McConnell, Dr Susan Friedman, Dr Reisner etc are all science based behavioural trainers with excellent resources On puppy training. If you’re in California Linda Michaels is in SAN Diego and @steffenbaldwin is LA adjacent. Stay away from Off Leash K9 or Bark Busters as they are all promoters of harmful tools that can damage your relationship with your dog.

kennaconfetti: Routine. Routine. Routine. Simple one word commands for actions and tricks, agree on terms (sit vs. sit down or down vs. lay down) and be consistent.

deschats_rouge: May you have too many wonderful years to count. I recommend clicker training.

rockingmama: Congratulations! Find a great trainer (online, book, etc) and stick to it. 15 minutes every day and you'll have an amazing friend. Decide what you want 🥖X for (companion, road trip buddy, home protection) and focus the training there. Also have fun! Commands don't have to be stay sit heal. You can make up words. You can use crazy words. The dog will never know! They'll just respond to whatever you train them to. 💜❤️💜

katesk106: I’m sure you’ve looked into this, but just in case, many houseplants are poisonous to dogs/cats. We had to “cat proof” our plants recently and I was surprised how many are toxic. https://balconygardenweb.com/poisonous-houseplants-for-dogs-plants-toxic-to-dogs/
chelseythegreatt: Puppies pee all the time 😂😂 I had to take mines out 4-5 times a day for quick little pees. And smaller dogs are harder to potty train, so be patient. Being patient and understanding is my biggest tip for puppies and for smaller dogs. I have 3 😂😂
its.el.now: SO CUTE! Congrats! I have a lot of advice: - Make sure that the pupper has plenty of healthy things to chew on! Invest in sturdy bones. Animal bones are not always a good option (plus they stink up the couch!) - If BaguetteX is biting themself or smells yeasty it may mean that they have allergies to food or environment (esp if they’re from breeder!) Get them seen by a vet!
beydems: Socializing is very important and can only be done when they are little. Expose your pup to everything and everyone, provided they are vaccinated. Get lots of chew toys. Puppies can only hold their bladder for as many months as they are old (2 months = 2 hours). I read Training The Best Dog Ever and it helped so much with my pup. Best of luck! The early weeks can be the hardest but patience, consistency, and positivity go a very long way! 💛
theblackplanter: Omg! Too cute! Congrats on the new addition to the fam
northwoods_hill_farmers: -Crate training works for some families. -Make sure to potty Baguette every hour for her month age, for example, 8 weeks=2 months=potty every two hours, 3 months=potty every 3 hours, etc. and especially after play and eating/drinking. -Celebrate successful potties, (we dance and sing a little song, give pets, etc.). -When dealing with puppies, like with kids, I try to “catch them doing something good”. -Bottle the puppy breath ♥️♥️♥️

thewildkindness: Congratulations! I got my first ever dog (Cavapoo) last fall when he was eight weeks old. I recommend two books: The Art of Raising A Puppy and The Other End of the Leash. (I did get him as an emotional support animal and was already going through a very hard time when he arrived and the first few weeks were SO hard. I cried a lot and doubted my decision but with support from friends and family I got through, and now consider that very difficult adjustment period to have been worth it). Much love and luck.
yaicha: Omg PERFECT BABY! 😭 My main advice is to get it some training classes once it has all its shots etc. We took our baby to Petco Unleashed and they’re great and it was worth every penny.
__allie_: I’d say definitely be careful with what human food/leftovers you feed them because these breeds can have quite sensitive stomachs compared to bigger dogs, at least that’s what I’ve experienced with me and my sister’s pooch (cavapoo) and the same goes for stuff outside. We made the mistake of not teaching ours to let us open her mouth from young so we’ve had to do it more recently because she’d get possessive over whatever she would pick up and that can be dangerous because you never know what gross stuff they can find/eat. Other than that I agree with who has said general obedience/basic training because it helps a lot in the long run. This is so beautiful, thanks for sharing the cuteness with us all and enjoy the magic of having a little furbabe, lots of love to all three of you ♥️✨🙏🏼
hotbibabe: Lots of praise & some treats when they poop or pee outside!

amrieej: OMG CONGRATS ON YOUR FUR BABY!!
veggiekales_: Crate. Train. It will save you so many headaches. Some dogs pick up on it easily without much anxiety. Some dogs struggle. Getting them used to a kennel early on will be the best thing you ever did, they view their kennel as a safe space/home and treat it as such. Positive reinforcement is great too! Treats for every positive behavior they do, whether it’s intentional or not, will help them learn what behaviors they get rewarded for and continue doing them until it becomes natural. I’m so excited for you and Eb! It’ll be hard raising a puppy at first but also SO much fun!
rowena_kosher: Congratulations! Baguette X is so cute!! Tips: routine routine routine. Potty routine, bedtime routine, food routine, walk routine! Dogs function well when they don’t have to make too many decisions. And socialize early!

ig4steve: So happy for you both! For you three❤️. As a second time small dog owner my best advice is to not baby your pup too much. ashmarie2112: Take them out every 2 hours. They will cry at night at first if in a cage (ours sleeps in our bed😂)
syndrome_air: YAYYYEEEEEE WHAT A SWEET BREAD!! Congratulations!! Oh my god! 😭😍❤️ My best advice is to get them on a feeding schedule as soon as you can! Usually it’s twice a day depending on the breed, it could be more/less, but generally puppies from breeders are given food all day to eat at their leisure. This can lead to food-aggression/resource guarding which is honestly such a pain for you and your dog. Also treat every toy and food as if it is yours first and you are simply sharing it with your pup. Take toys, beds, treats/bones away randomly and then give them back so your dog knows not to feel anxious about guarding it. This is one thing that can develop early on and it’s really tough to reverse it, so it’s good to nip it while they are young! This is advice I wish I had when we got our puppy! Best of luck, you and Eb will be amazing dog parents!!!

jamiejleclaire: Yay 👏 Fire baby! 🔥 Puppy tip: As super cute as they are, they can be overwhelmingly hyper. ms.smashley.rose: If you look into pet insurance, do it sooner rather than later. From what I understand none of them cover pre-existing conditions, so getting in early is best. And congrats!! What a sweet lil face!!! 💕😍💕

msindiarose: Oh my goodness! Congrats on yalls lil baby
jessye__: Awwww 😫 next it’s gonna be babies and I’m not going to be able to deal with y’all family cuteness all over again😢. I’ve had puppies! So my advice is... schedule schedule schedule! Puppy pads in one specific area and NOT where he/she sleeps. As soon as he/she eats wait 5-10 minutes and take his/her little booty outside. Remember to say “outside” or “bathroom” or “potty time” when you do so he/she gets use to hearing it when it’s time. Don’t come in until he’s/she’s done his/her business and treats when him/her learns that is where they go. Puppies should go outside to potty at least 4-5 times a day. Repeating commands with little treats will get him/her to learn quicker and faster mine were “bed”, “sit”, “stay” and “outside” bed so he/she knows where to go when you both leave the home until you all are comfortable with her/him being kennel trained and potty trained 😊❤️ congrats on your new fur baby!!
nuncia_maria: Omg!!! So sweet. We got a puppy in October, and the one thing I would say is stick to your housebreaking plan or you will have a 10 month old who pees on your bedroom floor. (Hypothetically. lol) good luck!!
